Has anyone else considered the possibility of a 3rd, 4th or even 5th alternative as to how life got to point it is at now and that the reason we currently lack knowledge about it is either that we are not at a stage where we can intellectually consider it or that key pieces of evidence have not yet been found? 
 
 So from both sides: are you willing to admit that evolution and creation could be in fact false?
pandion

Am I willing to consider that there are other possibilities? Sure. But based on the evidence we have now, the theories of evolution are the best explanations for the observed facts. But to replace evolutionary theory you need to do a better job of explaining every observation from the last 150 years. It's possible, but not likely. I'll wait to see the evidence.
 
 On the other hand, evolutionary theory and science in general has offered a better, more logical, and natural explaination for every claim of creationism, except the ultimate "GODDIDIT."
Duo_Maxwell

of course, our current understanding of life as we know it is biology and evolution is far better then the idiotic notion of creation, but that does not rule out the possibility of other alternatives. It is truly arrogant to say that we have found the answer when in the past fellow scientists have believed what we now know to be truly moronic as geniune scientific facts. 
 
 Like it said, a possible reason for why we have not found a plausible alternative is because we are not at the intellectual stage to either come up with it or understand it.

 Even the conept of suggesting that reason, as we use it today, is somehow insufficient for understanding everything, is irrational. By what mechanism would something elude logic (the basis for reason)? It would have to be illogical...do you suggest the realm of the illogical is hiding logical answers?
 
 -Mach

 and mach goes off again.

 Btw: no one even talked about reason except for you.

 
 
 Dreams are a wonderful thing, until they are brought forth into the light of day.
 
 
the reason we currently lack knowledge about it is either that we are not at a stage where we can intellectually consider it 
 
 
 This seems to me to suggest that you think it may be possible that we aren't able to "reason" certain things at this stage in human development.
 
 What is it you suggest we are lacking in terms of intellectual ability?
 What problem is currently not "solvable" that we need need some mystic super-intelligence to tackle?
 
 
are we at the peak of our intellectual ability and reasoning?

 
 Reason hasn't changed that much, it's just been refined to be consistent, it's not on a growth curve, it's a flat line. There is not a logical problem that exists that isn't able to be broken down into a decision tree of 0s and 1s. I know that's boring, don't blame me, blame the "creator".
 
 As to intellectual ability, by no means do we need to be at our peak, bio-engineering and good old fashioned CPUs are now, and likely in the future, going to continue expanding the decision cycle time and storage capacity of humanities collective minds.
 
 But this doesn't further the argument. We can easily name problems that require more computing power than we currently wield. Predicting weather patterns, for instance, require vastly superior computing than we can currently achieve Most cancers, for intance, still elude us, but we have no reason to believe our minds are somehow deficient. Indeed, we have unravled some. But we didn't use anything other than the same logic that Aristotle put onto pages.
 
 I realize I jump to the end sometimes, but most ideas and arguments end up taking on similar for. The choices are this:
 
 1. It's an insolvable problem. For example - if reality as we know it is found undeniably to be probablistic, then it's not finite in solution (4% chance of this, 10% chance of that, etc.) Worse still, it's just not a real problem (illogical).
 
 2. It's solvable, and we only lack computing cycles or storage capacity.
 
 Of course, Jim said the same thing but in one sentence (chalk it up to his greater experience on this rock)
 
 
If there were a third or fourth alternative, what would be its description?

 There may be a third, fourth etc way, but we currently have no knowledge of them if that is the case and thus no way to describe them.

However, the question was to consider a 3rd (or greater) option regarding how we got here, the first being instant creation and the second being time-release creation.
 
 Conjure up a third alternative, please.
zachvac

People talk about a third or fourth option. I'm still looking for a first. Evolution doesn't address how everything started. What happened before single-celled organisms? How did they get there?
 
 Same with creationism. Even if we assume it's correct (which I don't) where did God come from? You can always go further back in time unless time itself was created, which is even harder to comprehend.

This seems to me to suggest that you think it may be possible that we aren't able to "reason" certain things at this stage in human development.

 I'm just saying that we may be in a position where we lack the ability or the intelligence to think of a 3rd option. Clive already gave a perfect example, that of Newton and Quantam Mechanics. There's no way he could have thought of that at that time. I don't see any difference between us replacing newton and something else replace quantam mechanics. We are by no means at the peak of our intelligence, and assuming that our systems of reasoning exclude other possibilities is just arrogant, and historically false. 
 
 
I realize I jump to the end sometimes, but most ideas and arguments end up taking on similar for.

But this doesn't further the argument. We can easily name problems that require more computing power than we currently wield. Predicting weather patterns, for instance, require vastly superior computing than we can currently achieve Most cancers, for intance, still elude us, but we have no reason to believe our minds are somehow deficient.

Mach

assuming that our systems of reasoning exclude other possibilities is just arrogant, and historically false.

 The entire system of science is built specifically to always accept new evidence and self-correct, no possibilities are excluded by science, or by me.
 
 
You are a evolutionist, and it would seem evolutionists and creationists often do that very thing: jump to the end. 
 
 The difference is, I jump to the end of the logical conclusion, which in this case is:
 As I said before, if it IS possible, it's possible.
 This agrees with most of what you say. If you can pose an idea that is logically consistent with science, about how life originated, and no one can show it to be false, then it's for all practical purposes, a possibility, and you can become it's champion, and while people may think you waste your time on a fringe possibility, you would be not be incorrect to claim it "could be the answer".
 
 
Deficient or merely not a the stage required for understanding? Try ponder the Newton Quantam Mechanics analogy for a second. 

 
 But I think Jim already did. 
 Either a consciousness was involved in the creation of life on earth (first life), or no consciousness was involved. 
 
 That's really all we can say, there is no third option in that framework.
 
 But I jump to the end because one possibility is insufficient. Given what we know, if there WAS consciousness directly responsible for the initiation of the process, then creation (natural, not supernatural) is true, and evolution follows. If no consciousness was directly responsible for initiating the process, then creation is false, and evolution follows after some non-creation event.
 
 BUT, if natural creation is true, we must then discover what process started the natural creator's life chain. It seems reasonable that within the universe, life can only ultimately originate from the universe, and not a consciousness, else, it wouldn't be consistent. You would be claiming that a consciousness within the universe, existed before universe existed, which doesn't work. That's why the argument always ends with the same conclusion. If the universe has a beginning (big bang), then the only logical origin for life, is the universe itself. 
 
 I sure would think it's cool if we find a rift in space that gods and what not come poking into our universe through, but we can't call that a possibility yet.
 
 These are examples of possible possibilities (So I can be constructive on your thread)
 1. Something that exists outside our universe created our universe (which is the same as creating us).
 2. Something that exists outside our universe can manipulate our universe through PROBABALISTIC variation.
 3. What we observe is not reality, and our entire framework of reality is not actually "real" (brain in a vat, or more recently, the matrix)
 
 I think any of these may be revelaed through gaining more facts (knowledge). We have the ability to know ANYTHING, we may just not have all the facts.
 
 -Mach
Mach

That sort of blows my mind.
 If the universe does indeed operate by the fundamental laws it seems to, then we are part of the universe...literally the same as a "limb" of the universe, woven directly into the fabric of the entire universe. We have no free will, we don't "do" anything, it's the universe that is doing the doing.
 
 In that example, we could NOT be created by definition, nothing except the universe itself could be "created" in a literal sense, and we are just part of it, and each other, all the same "thing". Relativity confused even Einstein and he wrote the math on it, it still confuses me regularly.
 
 -Mach

We are not ignorant of a third option here because there is none. We got here by one of two ways...either we were created in our present form and we continued to procreate or we were created in another form and evolved to what we are. It has nothing to do with who or what created us.
Possible "third way" options:
 
 1. We weren't created, we came into existence through purely naturalistic means.
 2. We weren't created as we, along with the rest of the universe, are an illusion, computer simulation or whatever.
 3. Humans were created in their present form, all other life evolved (or any combination of species evolving/ not evolving).
 
 The problem with dichotomies, is they invariably false.

 Anything that exists was either made in its present from or was made in some other form and then changed to its present form. There is no other alternative.
Alan Ryan

There are infinitely many logically possible combinations of matter under an infinite number of logically possible sets of natural laws, so the existence of any particular material objects under any set of natural laws is highly improbable - would they all need a God ? 
 
 A singular option - that we might call "reality" and which is the only option of which we can claim any knowledge - includes all the natural phenomena, and its evolution, so far verified by science. This reality does not require a first cause in the form of God for the reason suggested above.

Nwarth

here is something strange... if we want to hold on to the law of non-contradictions: that is either something is the case or it is not the case, and we want to espouse that God is the Creator, who created everything, then we can ask, who created God? If God was never 'created' then how can he create himself, for he had to create everything? Yet if God was created how could he create himself for how can something self-create (and not in the Sartre existential sense)? A curious paradox no? The only answer I see is to deny that he is the Creator or creator of all things, and that is something that many people would be weary to give up. Or to restate saying "God created everything... except himself" which simply sounds like a silly excuse to avoid the paradox. 
 
 This paradox was motivated by B. Russell and was first found by him in the works of G. Frege.
jim's trucking

here is something strange... if we want to hold on to the law of non-contradictions: that is either something is the case or it is not the case, and we want to espouse that God is the Creator, who created everything, then we can ask, who created God? If God was never 'created' then how can he create himself, for he had to create everything? Yet if God was created how could he create himself for how can something self-create (and not in the Sartre existential sense)? A curious paradox no? The only answer I see is to deny that he is the Creator or creator of all things, and that is something that many people would be weary to give up. Or to restate saying "God created everything... except himself" which simply sounds like a silly excuse to avoid the paradox.

The only thing left out of this is the widely held view that we are incapable of fully understanding who or what God is. In this case, I believe there is a shortcoming in our logic system. "If a, then b" might not apply here.
 
 I'm no Bible thumper, but it does say "In the beginning was the Word and the Word was God...". By our logic, this means God existed before anything else. Comprehending that is likely impossible...believing it is not.
 
 Maybe God is just a word.
Nwarth

ahh but don't you see, I'm not necessarily using if then logic, but mostly the law of non-contradiction and distributed middle.
 
 If you argue God has always existed you also can't claim that he Created everything. Why? because then the question can be asked, who created him?
jim's trucking

ahh but don't you see, I'm not necessarily using if then logic, but mostly the law of non-contradiction and distributed middle.
 
 If you argue God has always existed you also can't claim that he Created everything. Why? because then the question can be asked, who created him?
Perhaps we both need corrective lenses.
 
 Your very statement:
 
 either something is the case or it is not the case
...is a pair of "If A then B" statements.
 
 If something is the case, then it cannot be not the case.
 If something is not the case, then it cannot be the case.
 
 In this case "in the case" is defined as satisfying or falling within the description of a particular topic of concern.
 
 I had it put to me slightly differently by a quick-witted girlfriend..."it's either in the bag or it ain't"...meaning it's either (within) the case or it ain't (within) the case. If it ain't in the case, then it's outside the case.
 
 By man's strict logic, what you say makes sense. However, I believe God transcends our logic in more ways than this one. How God came to be may never be understood by man.
 
 If you can't see this, then you need glasses. ;)
